trans-unit.source: How to: Use an Error URL for Custom Error Handling
trans-unit.target: How to: Use an Error URL for Custom Error Handling

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: How to: Use an Error URL for Custom Error Handling
trans-unit.target: How to: Use an Error URL for Custom Error Handling

trans-unit.source: Applies To
trans-unit.target: Applies To

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: This topic explains how to use the Error URL feature to implement custom login error handling in a relying party application.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains how to use the Error URL feature to implement custom login error handling in a relying party application.

trans-unit.source: An Error URL allows you to send errors that <token>secondref_acs</token> generates back to the relying party application so the application can log and respond to errors.
trans-unit.target: An Error URL allows you to send errors that <token>secondref_acs</token> generates back to the relying party application so the application can log and respond to errors.

trans-unit.source: For example, ASP.NET web sites can use the Error URL feature to present error messages to end users that are branded with the same look and feel as the website.
trans-unit.target: For example, ASP.NET web sites can use the Error URL feature to present error messages to end users that are branded with the same look and feel as the website.

trans-unit.source: Contents
trans-unit.target: Contents

trans-unit.target: Objectives

trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.target: Summary of Steps

trans-unit.source: Objectives
trans-unit.target: Objectives

trans-unit.source: Identify the required configuration for using the Error URL feature.
trans-unit.target: Identify the required configuration for using the Error URL feature.

trans-unit.source: Identify the helper code required to process error messages from <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Identify the helper code required to process error messages from <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Identify and troubleshoot potential pitfalls.
trans-unit.target: Identify and troubleshoot potential pitfalls.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: An Error URL specifies the web address to which <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects users if an error occurs during the login process.
trans-unit.target: An Error URL specifies the web address to which <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects users if an error occurs during the login process.

trans-unit.source: The Error URL target is typically a custom error page that is hosted by the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: The Error URL target is typically a custom error page that is hosted by the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: As part of the redirect, <token>secondref_acs</token> returns information about the error to the relying party application as a JSON-encoded HTTP URL parameter.
trans-unit.target: As part of the redirect, <token>secondref_acs</token> returns information about the error to the relying party application as a JSON-encoded HTTP URL parameter.

trans-unit.source: You can include the JSON-encoded error information in the custom error page and/or display static help text.
trans-unit.target: You can include the JSON-encoded error information in the custom error page and/or display static help text.

trans-unit.source: The following is a sample of a JSON-encoded error message.
trans-unit.target: The following is a sample of a JSON-encoded error message.

trans-unit.source: {"context":null,"httpReturnCode":401,"identityProvider":"Google","timeStamp":"2010-12-17 21:01:36Z","traceId":"16bba464-03b9-48c6-a248-9d16747b1515","errors":[{"errorCode":"ACS30000","errorMessage":"There was an error processing an OpenID sign-in response."},{"errorCode":"ACS50019","errorMessage":"Sign-in was canceled by the user."}]}
trans-unit.target: {"context":null,"httpReturnCode":401,"identityProvider":"Google","timeStamp":"2010-12-17 21:01:36Z","traceId":"16bba464-03b9-48c6-a248-9d16747b1515","errors":[{"errorCode":"ACS30000","errorMessage":"There was an error processing an OpenID sign-in response."},{"errorCode":"ACS50019","errorMessage":"Sign-in was canceled by the user."}]}

trans-unit.target: Summary of Steps

trans-unit.source: Use the follow process to handle <token>secondref_acs</token> error messages:
trans-unit.target: Use the follow process to handle <token>secondref_acs</token> error messages:

trans-unit.target: Step 1 – Enable the Error URL Feature

trans-unit.source: Step 2 – Create the Error Helper Classes
trans-unit.target: Step 2 – Create the Error Helper Classes

trans-unit.source: Step 3 – Process a JSON-Encoded Error Message
trans-unit.target: Step 3 – Process a JSON-Encoded Error Message

trans-unit.source: Step 4 – Configure Anonymous Access to the Error Page
trans-unit.target: Step 4 – Configure Anonymous Access to the Error Page

trans-unit.target: Step 5 – Test Your Work

trans-unit.source: Step 1 – Enable the Error URL Feature
trans-unit.target: Step 1 – Enable the Error URL Feature

trans-unit.source: To enable the Error URL feature for your relying party
trans-unit.target: To enable the Error URL feature for your relying party

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Relying party applications</ui> and select a relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Relying party applications</ui> and select a relying party application.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, enter your error page URL in the <ui>Error URL</ui> field.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, enter your error page URL in the <ui>Error URL</ui> field.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects user to this page when login errors occur.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects user to this page when login errors occur.

trans-unit.source: Also, <token>secondref_acs</token> sends JSON URL encoded parameters to this page that include the error details.
trans-unit.target: Also, <token>secondref_acs</token> sends JSON URL encoded parameters to this page that include the error details.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 – Create Error Helper Classes
trans-unit.target: Step 2 – Create Error Helper Classes

trans-unit.source: This step creates error helper classes that deserialize the JSON-encoded error messages.
trans-unit.target: This step creates error helper classes that deserialize the JSON-encoded error messages.

trans-unit.source: To create Error helper classes
trans-unit.target: To create Error helper classes

trans-unit.source: Add a class file to your web application and give it a name, such as <ui>Error.cs</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Add a class file to your web application and give it a name, such as <ui>Error.cs</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Implement the <ui>Error</ui> class as follows.
trans-unit.target: Implement the <ui>Error</ui> class as follows.

trans-unit.source: Add another class file and give it a name, such as <ui>ErrorDetails.cs</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Add another class file and give it a name, such as <ui>ErrorDetails.cs</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Implement the <ui>ErrorDetails</ui> class as follows.
trans-unit.target: Implement the <ui>ErrorDetails</ui> class as follows.

trans-unit.source: These classes will be used in the next step when processing error messages from <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: These classes will be used in the next step when processing error messages from <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 – Process a JSON-Encoded Error Message
trans-unit.target: Step 3 – Process a JSON-Encoded Error Message

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to process JSON-encoded error messages that <token>secondref_acs</token> generates.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to process JSON-encoded error messages that <token>secondref_acs</token> generates.

trans-unit.source: To process a JSON-encoded error message generated by ACS
trans-unit.target: To process a JSON-encoded error message generated by ACS

trans-unit.source: Add an ASPX web page to your ASP.NET application and give it a name, such as <ui>ErrorPage.aspx</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Add an ASPX web page to your ASP.NET application and give it a name, such as <ui>ErrorPage.aspx</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Add the following labels controls to the ASP.NET markup.
trans-unit.target: Add the following labels controls to the ASP.NET markup.

trans-unit.source: Switch to the page’s code-behind file, ErrorPge.aspx.cs.
trans-unit.target: Switch to the page’s code-behind file, ErrorPge.aspx.cs.

trans-unit.source: Add the following declaration to the top.
trans-unit.target: Add the following declaration to the top.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the <ui>Page_Load</ui> method.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the <ui>Page_Load</ui> method.

trans-unit.source: This code processes JSON-encoded error messages from <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This code processes JSON-encoded error messages from <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 – Configure Anonymous Access to the Error Page
trans-unit.target: Step 4 – Configure Anonymous Access to the Error Page

trans-unit.source: This step configures anonymous access to the ErrorPage.aspx file.
trans-unit.target: This step configures anonymous access to the ErrorPage.aspx file.

trans-unit.source: If the page is protected and requires authorization, an infinite redirection loop results.
trans-unit.target: If the page is protected and requires authorization, an infinite redirection loop results.

trans-unit.source: If this occurs when <token>secondref_acs</token> tries to access the page, <token>secondref_acs</token> sends a JSON-encoded error.
trans-unit.target: If this occurs when <token>secondref_acs</token> tries to access the page, <token>secondref_acs</token> sends a JSON-encoded error.

trans-unit.source: Because the error page can be accessed anonymously and it might include code that echoes back HTML and/or writes data to your database, you should make sure that you prevent cross-site scripting and SQL Injection attacks.
trans-unit.target: Because the error page can be accessed anonymously and it might include code that echoes back HTML and/or writes data to your database, you should make sure that you prevent cross-site scripting and SQL Injection attacks.

trans-unit.source: The following resources describe this in more detail:
trans-unit.target: The following resources describe this in more detail:

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>How To: Prevent Cross-Site Scripting in ASP.NET</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=178708</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=178708).
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>How To: Prevent Cross-Site Scripting in ASP.NET</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=178708</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=178708).

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>How To: Protect From Injection Attacks in ASP.NET</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=157572</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=157572).
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>How To: Protect From Injection Attacks in ASP.NET</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=157572</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=157572).

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>How To: Protect From SQL Injection in ASP.NET</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=212978</linkUri></externalLink> http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=212978.
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>How To: Protect From SQL Injection in ASP.NET</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=212978</linkUri></externalLink> http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=212978.

trans-unit.source: To configure anonymous access to the error page
trans-unit.target: To configure anonymous access to the error page

trans-unit.source: Open the web.config in your application and add the following entry.
trans-unit.target: Open the web.config in your application and add the following entry.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that access to your page does not cause an infinite redirection loop.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that access to your page does not cause an infinite redirection loop.

trans-unit.source: Step 5 – Test Your Work
trans-unit.target: Step 5 – Test Your Work

trans-unit.source: This step tests your Error URL configuration and implementation.
trans-unit.target: This step tests your Error URL configuration and implementation.

trans-unit.source: To enable the Error URL feature for your relying party
trans-unit.target: To enable the Error URL feature for your relying party

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Rule Groups</ui> and then click a rule group that is associated with the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Rule Groups</ui> and then click a rule group that is associated with the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: The following step cannot be undone.
trans-unit.target: The following step cannot be undone.

trans-unit.source: However, if you are deleting generated rules, they can be generated again easily.
trans-unit.target: However, if you are deleting generated rules, they can be generated again easily.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page, select all of the rules in the <ui>Rules</ui> section, and then click <ui>Delete Selected Rules</ui>.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page, select all of the rules in the <ui>Rules</ui> section, and then click <ui>Delete Selected Rules</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Save</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Save</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Return to your website and navigate to one of the pages using your browser.
trans-unit.target: Return to your website and navigate to one of the pages using your browser.

trans-unit.source: You should be redirected to your identity provider for authentication—<token>ms_acct</token>, Google, Facebook, Yahoo!, or <token>secondref_adfs2</token>—whatever is configured for your relying party as the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: You should be redirected to your identity provider for authentication—<token>ms_acct</token>, Google, Facebook, Yahoo!, or <token>secondref_adfs2</token>—whatever is configured for your relying party as the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: After successful authentication you should be redirected back to <token>secondref_acs</token>, which should generate an error since no rules are defined.
trans-unit.target: After successful authentication you should be redirected back to <token>secondref_acs</token>, which should generate an error since no rules are defined.

trans-unit.source: This error should be displayed on your error page that you created in <link xlink:href="94214df7-11f8-478e-b5ef-4b48fefb012e#BKMK_3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Step 2 – Create Error Helper Classes</link>, and will be similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: This error should be displayed on your error page that you created in <link xlink:href="94214df7-11f8-478e-b5ef-4b48fefb012e#BKMK_3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Step 2 – Create Error Helper Classes</link>, and will be similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: uri:WindowsLiveID Error Code ACS50000: There was an error issuing a token.
trans-unit.target: uri:WindowsLiveID Error Code ACS50000: There was an error issuing a token.

trans-unit.source: Another way to test this is to deny user consent.
trans-unit.target: Another way to test this is to deny user consent.

trans-unit.source: This is presented when you log on using Facebook or Google.
trans-unit.target: This is presented when you log on using Facebook or Google.
